awd_titl_txt: Networked Nanophotonic Devices for Stem Cell Regulation: From Optogenetics to Optogenomics
awd_abstract_narration:
Major breakthroughs in the field of genomics, embryonic stem cell (ESC) biology, optogenetics and biophotonics are enabling the control and monitoring of biological processes through light. This project will develop the first steps towards the control and monitoring of stem cell regulation processes with single-cell resolution and real-time operation. Novel nanophotonic devices will activate/inactivate gene expression and, thus, control stem cell differentiation in neuronal cells. Light-controlled protein-protein interactions and nanophotonic devices will be utilized to control genome function. New discoveries and findings from this project will be incorporated into existing and new courses, and a new cross-departmental course will be developed.

By incorporating light-actuated/light-emitting proteins into cells, key biological processes at the sub-cellular level can be controlled and monitored in real time. Cell development and fate can be effectively regulated by targeting key genes in the cell pluripotency network. Broadband sources will be utilized to illuminate two interleaved plasmonic nano-antenna arrays designed to resonate at the required frequencies.  Nano-lasers at 650 nm and 750 nm will be developed, which will provide spatial and temporal control of the illuminated area.  Nanophotonic devices and the optogenomic constructs that are developed will be utilized for the first time to control genome function through regulation of gene activities and DNA topology.

por.por_cntn:
The key outcomes of effort compromise fundamental scientific contributions, applied engineering techniques, and translational solutions relating to the development of a programmable platform able to active and deactivate the expression of targeted genes in neuronal cells by means of light-controlled protein-protein interactions. More specifically, the light-controlled molecular toggle-switch based on Plant Phytochrome B (PhyB) and transcription factor Pif6 are utilized to control the nuclear fibroblast growth factor receptor-1 (nFGFR1), which is a master regulator of stem cell differentiation. To achieve this goal, major contributions have been made relating to 1) the development of nanophotonic devices that can target individual neuronal cells to active or deactivate protein-protein interactions; 2) the development of the optogenomic construct based on PhyB/Pif6; and 3) the use of the nanophotonic devices with the PhyB/Pif6 molecular toggle switch for the study of cell pluripotency, neuronal differentiation and chromatin topology. During this project, we have simultaneously advanced the state of the art in the multiple relating disciplines (nanophotonics, neuroscience, genomics), always with an eye towards practical implementation.  This work has been completed by an interdisciplinary team with expertise across electrical and computer engineering, neuroscience, genomics and cell biology, originally all at the University at Buffalo. Through the duration of this project, multiple students including undergraduate and graduate female engineers and students from other under-represented minorities, have been trained and mentored. Finally, beyond the original vision, multiple side projects have been originated from this research, including innovative joint nanoscale communication and bio-sensing systems for the next generation of intra-body wireless networks.
